The Coolgardie scheme is all right and I could finish it if I got a chance and protection from misrepresentation but there's no hope for that now and its better that it should be given to some entirely new man to do who will be untrammelled by prior responsibility. 10/3/02 Put the wing walls to Helena Weir at once

At least in my case it is prompted by a vague sense of anxiety—about my own future. — As for my vague sense of anxiety about my own future, I think I analyzed it all in 'A Fool's Life,' except for a social factor, namely the shadow of feudalism cast over my life. This I omitted purposely, not at all certain that I could really clarify the social context in which I lived. — P.S. Reading a life of Empedocles, I felt how old is this desire to make a god of oneself. This letter, so far as I am conscious, never attempts this. On the contrary, I consider myself one of the most common humans. You may recall those days of twenty years ago when we discussed 'Empedocles on Etna'—under the linden trees. In those days I was one who wished to make a god of myself.

I was greatly embarrassed. One of two things was inevitable—either to violate the law or condemn my friend. After careful consideration, I devised this expedient. I delivered with such address all the most plausible arguments in behalf of the accused, that my two colleagues found no difficulty in acquitting him, and yet I, myself, condemned him to death without assigning any reason for my conduct. Thus I discharged two duties, those of friend and judge; yet I feel in my conscience something which makes me doubt whether my conduct was not criminal.

name: Titus
title: Roman emperor
quote: My life is taken from me, though I have done nothing to deserve it; for there is no action of mine of which I should repent, but one.

name: Rabbi Akiva
title: Jewish scholar and sage
quote: Hear, O Israel! The Lord is our God! The Lord is One!
context: reciting the Shema Yisrael while being executed by the Romans

name: Hadrian
title: Roman emperor
quote: O my poor soul, whither art thou going?

name: Polycarp
title: Christian bishop of Smyrna
quote: O Lord God Almighty, Father of Thy well-beloved Son, Jesus Christ, by whom we have received knowledge of Thee; God of angels, powers, and every creature that lives before Thee; I thank Thee that Thou hast graciously thought me worthy of this day and hour, that I may receive a portion in the number of Thy martyrs, and drink of Christ's cup, for the resurrection of both soul and body unto life eternal, in the incorruptibleness of the Holy Spirit. Among them may I be admitted this day, as an acceptable sacrifice, as Thou, O true and faithful God, hast prepared, foreshown, and accomplished. Wherefore, I praise Thee for all Thy mercies. I bless Thee. I glorify Thee, with Jesus Christ, Thy beloved Son, the Eternal, to Whom, with Thee and the Holy Spirit, be glory now and forever.
context: prior to martyrdom by burning and spearing

name: Antoninus Pius
title: Roman emperor
context: giving the password for the night-watch

name: Demonax
title: Greek Cynic philosopher
quote: You may go home, the show is over.

name: Marcus Aurelius
title: Roman emperor and philosopher
quote: Go to the rising sun, for I am setting. Think more of death than of me.

name: Didius Julianus
title: Roman emperor
quote: But what evil have I done? Whom have I killed?
context: to his assassin.

name: Septimius Severus
title: Roman emperor
quote: Hurry, if anything remains for me to do.

name: Saint Lawrence
title: Christian deacon
quote: I am roasted,—now turn me, and eat me.
context: while being burned alive on a gridiron

name: Cyprian
title: Christian bishop of Carthage and martyr
context: sentenced to death by beheading

name: Plotinus
title: Hellenistic philosopher
quote: I am making my last effort to return that which is divine in me to that which is divine in the Universe.

name: Anthony the Great
title: Christian monk from Egypt
quote: And let my word be kept secret by you, so that no one knows the place but you alone. For in the resurrection of the dead I shall receive my body incorruptible once again from the Savior. Distribute my clothing. To Bishop Athanasius give the one sheepskin and the cloak on which I lie, which he gave to me new, but I have by now worn out. And to Bishop Serapion give the other sheepskin, and you keep the hair garment. And now God preserve you, children, for Antony is leaving and is with you no longer.

name: Marcus of Arethusa
title: Christian bishop and martyr
quote: How am I advanced, despising you that are upon the earth!
context: hung up in a honey-smeared basket for bees to sting him to death

name: Julian
title: Roman emperor
quote: And yet Thou hast conquered, O Galilean!
context: mortally wounded in battle. He had rejected Christianity in favor of paganism; according to some accounts, he was assassinated by a Christian.

name: Saint Monica
title: mother of Augustine of Hippo
quote: In peace I will sleep with Him and take my rest.

name: Severus of Ravenna
title: Bishop of Ravenna
quote: My dear one, with whom I lived in love so long, make room for me, for this is my grave, and in death we shall not be divided.
context: According to a traditional story, Severus laid himself in his family tomb alongside his dead wife and daughter, then died

name: Ambrose
title: Bishop of Milan
quote: Old though he be, he is the best of all.
context: when Simplician was mentioned as his possible successor

name: Martin of Tours
title: third bishop of Tours
quote: What dost thou here, thou cruel beast?
context: to the Devil

name: Vakhtang I
title: Georgian monarch
quote: And me as I am going towards the God of mine, and I thank His name, as the Lord gave me everything bless His name. And I am telling you, to stand firm on your faith and to search for death for Christ for His name and you will find the permanent glory. I for my life glorified you and all of our race. And do not insult our home and do not abandon the love of the Greeks.
context: to his son Dachi

name: Columba
title: Irish abbot and missionary evangelist
quote: Here must I stop. What follows, let Baithen write.
context: ceasing to transcribe a Psalter

name: Phocas
title: Eastern Roman emperor
quote: Will you govern it any better?
context: to his successor Heraclius before being executed

name: Muhammad
title: Prophet of God in Islam
quote: Oh God, the Friend Most High!" or "The prayer, the prayer! And fear Allah with regard to those whom your right hands possess

name: Goar of Aquitaine
title: priest and hermit
quote: Here shall my Saviour be known in all the simplicity of his doctrines. Ah! would that I might witness it; but I have seen those things in a vision. But I faint! I am weary! My earthly journey is finished! Receive my blessing. Go! and be kind one to another.
context: dying in Oberwesel, Austrasia

name: Xuanzang
title: Chinese Buddhist monk, scholar, traveler and translator
quote: I desire that whatever merits I may have gained by good works may fall upon other people. May I be born again with them in the heaven of the blessed, be admitted to the family of Mi-le, and serve the Buddha of the future, who is full of kindness and affection. When I descend again upon earth, to pass through other forms of existence, I desire at every new birth to fulfill my duties toward Buddha, and arrive at the end to the highest perfect intelligence.

name: Yŏn Kaesomun
title: military dictator and generalissimo of Goguryeo
quote: You brothers must get along like fish and water and never fight each other for titles. If not, you will surely become the laughingstock of our neighbors.
context: to his sons

name: Bede
title: English Benedictine monk
quote: You speak truth, all is finished now. Glory to God.
context: to a scribe to whom he was dictating a translation of the Gospel of John

name: Charlemagne
title: European monarch
quote: Lord, into Thy hands I commend my spirit.
context: quoting Jesus

name: Louis the Pious
title: King of the Franks
context: after turning his face to the wall before dying

name: Ragnar Lodbrok
title: semi-legendary Norse chieftain
quote: The piglets would grunt if they knew how the old boar is suffering!
context: after being cast into a snakepit by King Ælla of Northumbria

name: Alfred the Great
title: king of the Anglo-Saxons
quote: Thou my dear son, set thee now beside me, and I will deliver thee true instructions. My son, I feel that my hour is coming. My countenance is wan. My days are almost done. We must now part. I shall to another world, and thou shalt be left alone in all my wealth. I pray thee (for thou art my dear child) strive to be a father, and a lord to thy people. Be thou the children's father, and the widow's friend. Comfort thou the poor, and shelter the weak; and, with all thy might, right that which is wrong. And, son, govern thyself, by law; then shall the Lord love thee, and God above all things shall be thy reward. Call thou upon him to advise thee in all thy need, and so shall he help thee, the better to compass that which thou wouldest.
context: to his son, Edward the Elder

name: Abd al-Rahman III
title: first Caliph of Córdoba (15 October 961)
quote: I have now reigned above fifty years in victory or peace; beloved by my subjects, dreaded by my enemies, and respected by my allies. Riches and honors, power and pleasure, have waited on my call, nor does any earthly blessing appear to have been wanting to my felicity. In this situation, I have diligently numbered the days of pure and genuine happiness which have fallen to my lot: they amount to Fourteen:—O man! place not thy confidence in this present world!

name: Ælfheah of Canterbury
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: You urge me in vain. I am not the man to provide Christian flesh for pagan teeth to devour, and it would be so acting if I delivered unto you that which the poor have laid by for their subsistence.
context: refusing to pay ransom before being killed by his Danish captors

name: Siward
title: Earl of Northumbria
quote: How shameful it is that I, who could not die in so many battles, should have been saved for the ignominious death of a cow! At least clothe me in my impenetrable breastplate, gird me with my sword, place my helmet on my head, my shield in my left hand, my gilded battle-axe in my right, that I, the bravest of soldiers, may die like a soldier.
context: dying of dysentery

name: Pope Gregory VII
quote: I have loved justice and hated iniquity; therefore I die in exile.
context: in exile in Salerno due to his conflicts with Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor

name: William the Conqueror
title: King of England
quote: Then to our blessed Lady Mary, the mother of God, I commend myself. May she, by her holy intercessions, reconcile me to our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. God be merciful to—
context: after hearing bell ringing Prime

name: Berengar of Tours
title: French Christian theologian
quote: I shall not long hesitate between conscience and the Pope, for I shall soon appear in the presence of God, to be acquitted, I hope; to be condemned, I fear.
context: dying in ascetic solitude on the island of Saint-Cosme near Tours

name: William II of England
quote: Shoot, Walter, in the devil's name!
context: to Walter Tirel, who allegedly shot the king in a hunting accident

name: Anselm of Canterbury
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: Yes, if it be His will, I shall obey it willingly. But were He to let me stay with you a little longer till I have resolved a problem about the origin of the soul, I would gladly accept the boon; for I do not know whether anyone will work it out when I am gone. If I could but eat, I think I should pick up a little strength. I feel no pain in any part of my body; only I cannot retain nourishment, and that exhausts me.

name: Ranulf Flambard
title: Norman Bishop of Durham and government minister
quote: I wished to do more harm than I could.

name: Bernard of Clairvaux
title: Burgundian abbot
context: on being told he was dying

name: Eric the Holy
title: Swedish king
quote: Let us complete the Service of Offering, the rest of Holy Mass I will celebrate elsewhere!
context: just before being decapitated by his successor Magnus Henriksson

name: Héloïse
title: French nun, philosopher, writer, scholar and abbess
quote: In death at last let me rest with Abelard.

name: Thomas Becket
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: For the name of Jesus and the protection of the church I am ready to embrace death.
context: to his murderers

name: Andronikos I Komnenos
title: Byzantine Emperor
quote: Lord, have mercy upon me. Wilt thou break a bruised reed?
context: lynched by his former subjects

name: Henry II of England
quote: Now let the world go as it will; I care for nothing more.
context: on being told his son John was one of those conspiring against him

name: Saladin
title: first sultan of Egypt and Syria
quote: When I am buried, carry my winding-sheet on the point of a spear, and say these words: Behold the spoils which Saladin carries with him! Of all his victories, realms, and riches, nothing remains to him but this.

name: Richard I of England
quote: Youth, I forgive thee! Take off his chains, give him 100 shillings, and let him go.
context: with reference to the young man who had mortally wounded him with a crossbow

name: Saint Dominic
title: Castilian Catholic priest, founder of the Dominican Order
quote: Under the feet of my friars.
context: when asked where he wanted to be buried

name: Francis of Assisi
title: Italian Catholic friar
quote: I have sinned against my brother, the ass.

name: Genghis Khan
title: warlord and khan of Mongolia
quote: Let not my end disarm you, and on no account weep or keen for me, lest the enemy be warned of my death.

name: Anthony of Padua
title: Portuguese Catholic priest and Franciscan friar
quote: I see my God. He calls me to Him.

name: Skule Bårdsson
title: Norwegian nobleman
context: before being killed by supporters of King Haakon IV of Norway

name: Simon de Montfort
title: 6th Earl of Leicester
quote: By the arm of St. James, it is time to die.
context: before dying at the Battle of Evesham

name: Conradin
title: last direct heir of the House of Hohenstaufen
quote: O my mother! how deep will be thy sorrow at the news of this day!
context: prior to execution by beheading at the age of 16

name: Louis IX of France
quote: I will enter thy house. I will worship in Thy sanctuary.

name: Thomas Aquinas
title: Italian dominican theologian and philosopher
quote: I have written and taught much about this very holy Body, and about the other sacraments in the faith of Christ, and about the Holy Roman Church, to whose correction I expose and submit everything I have written.
context: as he received his last rites

name: Rudolf I of Germany
quote: I am on the way to Spires to visit the kings, my predecessors.
context: he was buried at Speyer Cathedral

name: Edward I of England
quote: Carry my bones before you on your march, for the rebels will not be able to endure the sight of me, alive or dead.
context: to his son, Edward II of England, while dying during a war with Scotland

name: Jacques de Molay
title: last Grand Master of the Knights Templar

name: Thomas
title: 2nd Earl of Lancaster

context: before beheading for treason against his cousin, Edward II of England

name: Marco Polo
title: Venetian traveller in Asia

name: Edward the Black Prince
title: heir to the English throne

name: Edward III of England
context: kissing a crucifix

name: Wat Tyler
title: leader of the Peasants' Revolt
quote: Because they are all under my command, they are sworn to do what I bid them.
context: prior to being killed by officers loyal to Richard II of England

name: Gaston III
title: Count of Foix
quote: I am a dead man! Lord, have mercy upon me!
context: "Never yet has death been frightened away by screaming." — Timur, Turco-Mongol conqueror, founder of the Timurid Empire (17–19 February 1405)

name: Margaret
title: Queen of Denmark, Norway and Sweden
quote: We are now to sail home, at once!
context: afflicted with the plague in Flensburg harbor

name: Jan Hus
title: Czech theologian and church reformer
context: While being burned at the stake for heresy, he saw an old woman throw a small amount of brushwood onto the fire

name: Jerome of Prague
title: Czech scholastic philosopher and theologian
quote: O Lord God, Father Almighty, have mercy upon me, and be merciful unto mine offences, for thou knowest how sincerely I have loved Thy truth.
context: burned for heresy

name: Jan Žižka
title: Czech general
quote: Make my skin into drumheads for the Bohemian cause.

name: Giovanni di Bicci de' Medici

I recall nothing in my life with so much pleasure as having given offence to no one, and having tried to serve all men as far as possible. I advise you to act thus, if you would live securely, accepting only those honors as the laws and favor of the state confer upon you; for it is the exercise of power that has been violently—not voluntarily—obtained, that occasions hatred and strife.

name: Joan of Arc
title: French military leader and mystic
quote: Hold the cross high so I may see it through the flames!
context: while she was burning at the stake

name: Margaret Stewart
title: Dauphine of France
quote: Fie on life! Speak no more of it to me.

name: Pope Eugene IV (born Gabriele Condulmer)
quote: O Gabriel, Gabriel, better would it have been for you to have been neither pope, nor cardinal, nor bishop, but to have finished your days as you commenced them, following peaceably in the monastery the exercises of your order.

name: Henry Beaufort
quote: Will not all my riches save me? What, is there no bribing death?
context: Cardinal, Bishop of Winchester

name: Constantine XI
quote: God forbid that I should live as an Emperor without an Empire. As my city falls, I will fall with it. Whosoever wishes to escape, let him save himself if he can, and whoever is ready to face death, let him follow me.
context: Byzantine Empire, before charging into ottoman lines during the Fall of Constantinople, he was never seen again

name: John II of Castile
quote: Naciera yo hijo de un labrador e fuera fraile del Abrojo, que no rey de Castilla
context: King of Castile

name: Pachacuti
quote: I was born as a lily in the garden, and like the lily I grew, as my age advanced / I became old and had to die, and so I withered and died.
context: Sapa Inca and founder of the Inca Empire, poem composed on his deathbed

name: Louis XI
title: King of France
quote: Our Lady of Embrun, my good mistress, help me.

name: Richard III of England
context: when deserted by his best troops at the Battle of Bosworth Field

name: Wessel Gansfort
title: Dutch theologian and humanist
quote: I know only Jesus the crucified.

name: Charles VIII of France
quote: I hope never again to commit a mortal sin, nor even a venial one, if I can help it.

name: Girolamo Savonarola
title: Italian Dominican friar
quote: My Lord died innocent of all crimes, for my sins; and shall not I willingly give my soul for the love of Him.
context: when asked before his execution if he was resigned to death"All right, all right, I'm coming. Wait a moment." ("Va bene, va bene, arrivo. Aspettate un momento.") — Pope Alexander VI (18 August 1503)

name: Christopher Columbus
title: Italian explorer
quote: Into Your hands, O Lord, I commend my spirit.
context: quoting Jesus

name: Henry VII of England
quote: We heartily desire our executors to consider how behoofful it is to be prayed for.

name: Georges d'Amboise
title: French Roman Catholic cardinal and minister of state

name: Vasco Núñez de Balboa
title: Spanish explorer, governor and conquistador
quote: That is false. I always have served my king loyally and sought to add to his domains.
context: on hearing a herald call him a "usurper of the rights of the Crown" while on the way to his execution by decapitation

name: Leonardo da Vinci
title: Italian artist and scientist
quote: I have offended God and mankind because my work did not reach the quality it should have.
context: to King Francis I of France

name: Moctezuma II
title: Huey Tlatoani or Emperor of the Aztec Empire
quote: I confide to your care my beloved children, the most precious jewels I can leave you. The great monarch beyond the ocean will interest himself to see that they come into their inheritance, if you present before him their just claims. I know your master will do this, if for no other reason, then for the kindness I have shown the Spaniards, though it has occasioned my ruin. For all my misfortunes, Malinche, I bear you no ill will.
context: to Hernán Cortés (calling him by the name of his interpreter, La Malinche)

name: Pope Leo X
quote: I have been murdered; no remedy can prevent my speedy death.
context: rumored to have died by poison

name: Pietro Perugino

context: declining the last rites

name: Franz von Sickingen
title: German knight and Protestant leader

context: when his chaplain asked if he wanted to confess prior to his death defending his castle

name: Pierre Terrail
title: seigneur de Bayard, French knight

context: mortally wounded at the Battle of the Sesia (1524)

name: Niccolò Machiavelli
quote: I desire to go to hell, and not to heaven. In the former place I shall enjoy the company of popes, kings, and princes, while in the latter are only beggars, monks, hermits, and apostles.
context: Italian Renaissance diplomat, philosopher and writer

name: Patrick Hamilton
title: Scottish churchman
quote: How long, Lord, shall darkness cover this land? How long wilt thou suffer this tyranny of men? Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.
context: while being burned at the stake

name: Thomas Wolsey
title: English archbishop, statesman and cardinal
quote: And, Master Kyngston, had I but served God as diligently as I have served the king, he would not have given me over in my gray hairs. But this is my just reward for my pains and study, not regarding my service to God, but only my duty to my Prince.
context: ; to the Lieutenant of the Tower of London, after falling ill on the way to London under arrest for treason

name: Babur
title: founder of the Mughal Empire and first Emperor of the Mughal dynasty
quote: I give your brothers to your keeping. Be faithful to them and all the people.

name: Thomas Bilney
title: English Christian martyr
quote: I pray you, good people, be not the worse to these men on my account, as though they were the authors of my death.
context: While he awaited burning for heresy, the friars and people present argued over who was responsible for Bilney's death; the friars threatened to withhold alms from the people if they were blamed

name: Huldrych Zwingli
title: priest and leader of the Reformation in Switzerland
quote: Can this be considered a calamity? Well! they can, indeed, kill the body, but they are not able to kill the soul.
context: mortally wounded at the Battle of Kappel

name: James Bainham
title: English lawyer and Protestant reformer
quote: O ye papists: behold, ye look for miracles, and here now ye may see a miracle, for in this fire I feel no more pain than if I were in a bed of down, but it is to me as sweet as a bed of roses.
context: while burning at the stake for heresy

name: William Warham
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: That is enough to last till I get to Heaven.
context: when a servant told him he had thirty pounds left

name: Ludovica Albertoni
title: Italian noblewoman, professed member of the Third Order of Saint Francis
quote: Father, into Thy hands I commend my spirit.
context: quoting Jesus

name: Atahualpa
title: last Sapa Inca of the Inca Empire
quote: What have I done, or my children, that I should meet such a fate? And from your hands, too, you who have met with friendship and kindness from my people who have received nothing but benefits from my hands.
context: prior to execution by strangling

name: Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa
title: German polymath and occultist
quote: Begone thou wretched beast, which hast utterly undone me.
context: to his black dog (allegedly his familiar)

name: Thomas More
title: Lord High Chancellor of Britain
quote: I die the King's good servant, and God's first.
context: prior to beheading for treason

name: Catherine of Aragon
title: Queen of England

context: closing her last letter to her former husband, Henry VIII of England

name: Mark Smeaton
title: musician in the household of Queen Anne Boleyn
quote: Masters, I pray you pray for me, for I have deserved this death.
context: prior to beheading for alleged treason and adultery

name: Anne Boleyn
title: Queen of England
quote: Oh God, have pity on my soul. Oh God, have pity on my soul.
context: prior to her execution by beheading

name: Erasmus
title: Dutch Catholic priest and humanist scholar
quote: Lord! Lord! make an end! make an end!

name: William Tyndale
title: English scholar and Bible translator
quote: Lord, open the King of England's eyes.
context: before being strangled and burned at the stake for heresy

name: John Lambert
title: English Protestant martyr

name: Filippo Strozzi the Younger
title: Florentine banker

context: He carved this line from Virgil's Aeneid on a mantelpiece with his sword as his suicide note

name: Jerome Russell
title: Franciscan friar
quote: Death cannot destroy us, for it is destroyed already by Him for Whose sake we suffer.
context: burned for heresy in Scotland

name: Thomas Forret
title: vicar of Dollar, Clackmannanshire, burned for heresy

context: quoting Psalm 51

name: Francisco de San Roman
title: Spanish merchant and Protestant martyr
context: While burning at the stake, he moved his head in a way which caused the friars to believe he had recanted. Upon his removal from the flames, he asked them this question and was then returned to the fire

name: Thomas Cromwell
title: 1st Earl of Essex
quote: I die in the traditional faith.
context: prior to beheading for treason and heresy

name: Robert Barnes
title: English reformer and Protestant martyr
quote: I trust in no good works that ever I did, but only in the death of Christ. I do not doubt but through Him to inherit the kingdom of Heaven. But imagine not that I speak against good works, for they are to be done, and verily they that do them not shall never enter into the kingdom of God.
context: while being burned at the stake for heresy

name: Margaret Pole
title: Countess of Salisbury
quote: Blessed are they who suffer persecution for righteousness' sake.
context: quoting Matthew 5:10 while an incompetent executioner attempted to behead her

name: Francisco Pizarro
title: Spanish conquistador
context: after being stabbed by assassins

name: Hernando de Soto
title: Spanish explorer and conquistador
context: naming his successor

name: James V of Scotland
quote: It [the Crown of Scotland] came with a lass, and it will go with a lass.
context: on being informed of the birth of his daughter and successor, Mary, Queen of Scots

name: Nicolaus Copernicus
title: mathematician and astronomer
quote: Now, O Lord, set thy servant free.
context: paraphrasing Luke 2:29

name: Martin Luther
title: German theologian who started the Protestant Reformation
quote: We are beggars, this is true.

name: George Wishart
title: Scottish Protestant reformer and martyr
quote: Lo! here is a token that I forgive thee; my heart, do thine office.
context: kissing one of his executioners on the cheek after the man asked for his forgiveness

name: David Beaton
title: Archbishop of St Andrews, final Scottish Cardinal prior to the Scottish Reformation
quote: I am a priest; I am a priest! Fie! Fie! All is gone.
context: during his assassination

name: Anne Askew
title: English writer and poet
quote: I came not hither to deny my Lord and Master.
context: when offered letter of pardon before being burned at the stake for heresy

name: Henry VIII
title: King of England
quote: All is lost! Monks, monks, monks!

name: George Martinuzzi
title: Archbishop of Esztergom
context: while being assassinated

name: François Rabelais
title: French writer and physician
quote: Bring down the curtain, the farce is played out.

name: Michael Servetus
title: Spanish theologian, physician and humanist
quote: Jesus, Son of the eternal God, have mercy on me!
context: while being burned at the stake for heresy on a pyre of his own books

name: Lady Jane Grey
title: de facto Queen of England and Ireland
quote: Lord, into Thy hands I commend my spirit.
context: quoting Jesus prior to her beheading

name: Thomas Wyatt the Younger
title: English politician and leader of Wyatt's rebellion

context: exculpating Princess Elizabeth and Edward Courtenay, 1st Earl of Devon, prior to execution by beheading for treason

name: John Rogers
title: English clergyman, Bible translator and commentator
context: prior to burning at the stake for heresy

name: Laurence Saunders
title: English Protestant martyr

context: kissing the stake at which he was to be burned

name: John Hooper
title: Anglican Bishop of Gloucester and Worcester, Protestant martyr

context: refusing a pardon prior to burning at the stake for heresy

name: Rowland Taylor
title: English Protestant martyr

context: while being burned at the stake for heresy

name: William Hunter
title: English silk-weaver and Protestant martyr

context: while being burned at the stake for heresy

name: John Bradford
title: English Reformer and Protestant martyr

context: to John Leaf, a fellow martyr, prior to being burned at the stake

name: Nicholas Ridley
title: Bishop of London
quote: Let the flames come near me. I cannot burn! I cannot burn!
context: While burning at the stake for heresy, only his lower limbs burned away

name: Hugh Latimer
title: former Bishop of Worcester
quote: Be of good comfort, Master Ridley, and play the man; we shall this day light such a candle by God's grace in England as (I trust) shall never be put out.
context: ; to Nicholas Ridley while they were burning at the stake for heresy

name: Stephen Gardiner
title: English bishop and politician
quote: Like Peter, I have erred, unlike Peter, I have not wept.

name: Thomas Cranmer
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
quote: Lord Jesus, receive my spirit... I see the heavens open and Jesus standing at the right hand of God.
context: alluding to Acts 7:56 prior to execution by burning

name: Pietro Aretino
title: Italian writer and blackmailer

context: after receiving the last rites

name: Walter Milne
title: last Protestant martyr burned in Scotland before the Scottish Reformation
quote: Lord, have mercy upon me! Pray, people, while there is time.

name: Charles V
title: Holy Roman Emperor
quote: Now, Lord, I go! Ay, Jesus!
context: looking at a crucifix

name: Mary I of England
quote: After I am dead, you will find Calais written upon my heart.
context: French forces had captured Calais from England earlier that year

name: Philip Melanchthon
title: German Lutheran reformer
context: when asked if he wanted anything

name: Pierre de Bocosel de Chastelard
title: French poet

context: addressing the window of Holyrood Palace before being hanged for hiding under the bed of Mary, Queen of Scots

name: John Calvin
title: French theologian and Protestant reformer, principal developer of Calvinism
quote: Thou, Lord, bruisest me; but I am abundantly satisfied, since it is from thy hand.

name: Nostradamus
title: French seer
quote: Tomorrow, at sunrise, I shall no longer be here.
context: correctly predicting his death

name: Roger Ascham
title: English scholar and didactic writer
quote: I desire to die and be with Christ.

name: Bartolomeo Bartocci
title: Italian trader
context: while burning at the stake for heresy

name: Gaspard II de Coligny
title: Admiral of France

context: in response to one of his assassins asking, "Art thou Coligny?"

name: John Knox
title: founder of the Presbyterian Church of Scotland

name: Charles IX of France
quote: Nurse, nurse, what murder! what blood! Oh! I have done wrong. God pardon me!

name: Eric XIV
title: ex-King of Sweden
quote: Lord God, into Thy Holy Hands I commit my spirit.
context: when dying in prison from arsenic poisoning, quoting Jesus

name: Sebastian of Portugal

context: when being advised to surrender, and to hand over his sword to the victors of the Battle of Alcácer Quibir

name: George Buchanan
title: Scottish historian and humanist scholar
quote: It matters little to me; for if I am but once dead they may bury me or not bury me as they please. They may leave my corpse to rot where I die if they wish.
context: when his servant asked who would pay for his burial after Buchanan told him to distribute his property among the poor

name: Teresa of Ávila
title: Spanish Carmelite nun, mystic and author
quote: Over my spirit flash and float in divine radiancy the bright and glorious visions of the world to which I go.
context: ; last words uncertain

name: Fernando Álvarez de Toledo
title: 3rd Duke of Alba
context: on learning that the King was to visit him

name: Humphrey Gilbert
title: English adventurer and explorer
quote: We are as neare to Heaven by sea as by land.
context: prior to sinking of HMS Squirrel with all hands

name: William the Silent
title: Prince of Orange
quote: God have mercy upon me, and upon this poor nation.
context: assassinated by Balthasar Gérard

name: Vittoria Accoramboni
title: Italian noblewoman
context: kneeling before a crucifix

name: Anthony Babington
title: English gentleman, conspirator in the Babington Plot
quote: The murder of the Queen had been represented to me as a deed lawful and meritorious. I die a firm Catholic.
context: prior to being hanged, drawn and quartered for high treason

name: Philip Sidney
title: English poet and soldier
quote: Take it; thy need is greater than mine.
context: mortally wounded at the Battle of Zutphen, passing a cup of water to another wounded soldier

name: Mary
title: Queen of Scots
quote: O Lord, into Thy hands I commend my spirit.
context: quoting Jesus prior to execution by beheading

name: Frederick II of Denmark
quote: Let the pulse beat as it may, we know the mercy of God will never fail.

name: George Beesley
title: English Roman Catholic priest and martyr
quote: Absit mihi gloriari nisi in Cruce Domini Nostri Jesu Christi [Far from me to glory except in the cross of Jesus Christ]. Good people, I beseech God to send all felicity.
context: prior to execution

name: John of the Cross
title: Spanish Catholic priest and mystic
context: dying at the stroke of midnight

name: John III
title: King of Sweden
quote: I know that my Redeemer liveth.

name: John Woolton
title: Bishop of Exeter
quote: A bishop ought to die on his legs.

name: Torquato Tasso
title: Italian poet
quote: Lord, into Thy hands I commend my spirit.
context: quoting Jesus

name: William Whitaker
title: Calvinistic Anglican churchman, academic and theologian
quote: Life or death is welcome to me; and I desire not to live, but so far as I may be serviceable to God and His church.

name: Yi Sun-sin
title: Korean naval commander
context: telling his nephew to hide his death by gunshot from his soldiers to avoid demoralizing them during the Battle of Noryang

name: Giordano Bruno
title: Italian Dominican friar
quote: I die a martyr and willingly — my soul shall mount up to heaven in this chariot of smoke.
context: prior to burning at the stake for heresy

name: Richard Hooker
title: English priest and theologian
quote: Good Doctor, God hath heard my daily petitions, for I am at peace with all men, and He is at peace with me; and from that blessed assurance I feel that inward joy which this world can neither give nor take from me: my conscience beareth me this witness, and this witness makes the thoughts of death joyful. I could wish to live to do the Church more service, but cannot hope it, for my days are passed as a shadow that returns not.
context: "May I not seem to have lived in vain." ("Ne frustra vixisse videar.") — Tycho Brahe, Danish astronomer (24 October 1601), to his assistant Johannes Kepler

name: Elizabeth I
title: queen regnant of England
quote: All my possessions for a moment of time.

name: Akbar
title: third Mughal emperor
quote: I cannot bear that any misunderstanding should subsist between you and those who have for so many years shared in my toils and been the companions of my glory.
context: to his nobles and his son, Jahangir; he then asked their forgiveness if he had ever wronged them

name: Robert Catesby
title: leader of the Gunpowder Plot
quote: Stand by me, Tom, and we will die together.
context: Catesby and Thomas Percy were shot by armed men led by Sir Richard Walsh

name: Paolo Farinati
title: Italian Mannerist painter
context: on his deathbed. His wife replied, "I will bear you company, my dear husband," and also died

name: Joseph Justus Scaliger
title: French Calvinist religious leader and scholar
quote: I begin to perceive and feel the joys of eternal life. I shall soon behold Him, who was sacrificed for men; I long for the blessed sight. All else is to me as dross: there is nothing that could make me wish to live one hour longer.

name: Henry IV of France
context: while being assassinated by stabbing

name: François Ravaillac
title: French Catholic zealot, assassin of Henry IV of France
quote: I receive absolution upon this condition.
context: receiving conditional absolution prior to his execution due to his insistence that he had no accomplices

name: Robert Cecil
title: 1st Earl of Salisbury, English statesman
quote: Ease and pleasure quake to hear of death; but my life, full of cares and miseries, desireth to be dissolved.

name: Henry Frederick
title: Prince of Wales
quote: I would say 'somewhat,' but I cannot utter it.
context: when asked if he was in pain

name: John Ogilvie
quote: If there be here any hidden Catholics, let them pray for me, but the prayers of heretics I will not have.
context: hanged, drawn and quartered at Glasgow Cross because of having preached the Catholic religion, then illegal in Scotland, and for refusing to pledge allegiance to King James VI of Scotland

name: Sanada Yukimura
title: Japanese samurai warrior
quote: I am Sanada Nobushige, no doubt an adversary quite worthy of you, but I am exhausted and can fight no longer. Go on, take my head as your trophy.
context: to his foes prior to his death at the Battle of Tennōji

name: Miguel de Cervantes
title: Spanish novelist
quote: Already my foot is in the stirrup.

name: Robert Abbot
title: Anglican clergyman and academic
quote: Come Lord Jesu, come quickly, finish in me the work that Thou has begun; into Thy hands, O Lord, I commend my spirit, for Thou has redeemed me. O God of truth, save me Thy servant, who hopes and confides in Thee alone; let Thy mercy, O Lord, be shewn unto me; in Thee have I trusted, O Lord, let me not be confounded for ever.

name: Pocahontas
quote: All must die, but tis enough that the child liveth
context: dying of an unknown illness

name: Walter Raleigh
title: English poet, soldier and courtier
quote: What dost thou fear? Strike, man, strike!
context: as he lay ready to be beheaded in the Old Palace Yard at the Palace of Westminster

name: Lucilio Vanini
title: Italian philosopher, physician and freethinker

context: prior to execution by strangling and burning for atheism and blasphemy

name: Johan van Oldenbarnevelt
title: Dutch statesman
quote: Make it short. Make it short.
context: to his executioner

name: Philip III of Spain
quote: Oh, would to God I had never reigned! Oh, that those years I have spent in my kingdom I had lived a solitary life in the wilderness! Oh, that I had lived alone with God! How much more secure should I now have died! With how much more confidence should I have gone to the throne of God! What doth all my glory profit, but that I have so much the more torment in my death?

name: Johann Arndt
title: German Lutheran theologian
context: to his wife

name: Robert Bellarmine
title: Italian Jesuit and Roman Catholic cardinal

name: Rodrigo Calderón
title: Count of Oliva
quote: All my life I have carried myself gracefully.
context: when his confessor chastised him for his attention to his appearance prior to his execution by beheading

name: Paolo Sarpi
title: Venetian historian, prelate, scientist, canon lawyer and statesman
context: referring to Venice

name: Francis Bacon
title: English philosopher and statesman
quote: Thy creatures, O Lord, have been my books, but Thy Holy Scriptures much more. I have sought Thee in the fields and gardens, but I have found Thee, O God, in Thy Sanctuary—Thy Temple.

name: John Preston
title: Anglican minister, master of Emmanuel College, Cambridge
quote: Blessed be God, though I change my place, I shall not change my company; for I have walked with God while living, and now I go to rest with God.

name: George Villiers
title: 1st Duke of Buckingham
context: ; to his assassin, John Felton, after being stabbed by him

name: François de Malherbe
title: French poet, critic and translator
quote: Hold your tongue; your wretched style only makes me out of conceit with them.
context: listening on his deathbed to his confessor describing the glories of heaven

name: John Felton
title: assassin of George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham
context: referring to the killing of Buckingham before being executed by hanging

name: Pierre de Bérulle
title: French Roman Catholic cardinal and statesman
quote: I do bless.—May Jesus and Mary bless, rule and govern.
context: blessing his congregation while celebrating Mass

name: Agrippa d'Aubigné
title: French poet, soldier, propagandist and chronicler
quote: It comes at last, the happy day: Let thanks be given to God in heaven, while we learn pleasure in His way.

name: John Donne
title: English poet, scholar and soldier, Dean of St Paul's
quote: I were miserable, if I might not die.

name: Robert Bruce of Kinnaird
title: Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland
quote: Now, God be with you, my dear children; I have breakfasted with you, and shall sup with my Lord Jesus Christ this night.

name: Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden
quote: I have enough, brother; try to save your own life.
context: mortally wounded at the Battle of Lützen (1632)

name: George Herbert
title: Welsh-born poet, orator, and priest of the Church of England
quote: I am now ready to die. Lord, forsake me not, now my strength faileth me; but grant me mercy for the merits of my Jesus. And now Lord—Lord, now receive my soul.

name: Edward Coke
title: English barrister, judge and politician
quote: Thy kingdom come, thy will be done.

name: Lope de Vega
title: Spanish playwright
quote: All right then, I'll say it. Dante makes me sick.

name: William Bedell
title: Anglican Lord Bishop of Kilmore
quote: I have kept the faith once given to the saints; for the which cause I have also suffered these things; but I am not ashamed, for I know whom I have believed, and I am persuaded that He is able to keep that which I have committed to Him against that day.
context: dying from exposure after being imprisoned and tortured by rebels

name: Cardinal Richelieu
title: French clergyman and statesman
quote: Absolutely, and I pray God to condemn me, if I have had any other aim than the welfare of God and the state.
context: when asked whether he pardoned his enemies

name: John Hampden
title: English landowner and politician
quote: O Lord, save my country! O Lord, be merciful to—
context: mortally wounded at the Battle of Chalgrove Field six days before his death

name: Chongzhen Emperor
title: the last emperor of Ming dynasty
quote: It has been seventeen years since I ascended the throne. I, feeble and of small virtue, have offended against Heaven; the rebels have seized my capital because my ministers deceived me. Ashamed to face my ancestors, I die. Removing my imperial cap and with my hair disheveled about my face, I leave to the rebels the dismemberment of my body. Let them not harm my people!

name: William Laud
title: Archbishop of Canterbury
context: spoken as the signal to the executioner at his beheading for treason

name: Hugo Grotius
title: Dutch humanist, diplomat, lawyer, theologian and writer

name: Masaniello
title: Italian fisherman and revolutionary leader
context: to his assassins

name: George Lisle
title: Royalist leader in the English Civil War
quote: Ay! but I have been nearer to you, my friends, many a time, and you have missed me.
context: when the officer in charge of his firing squad said they would hit him

name: Charles I of England
context: asking for his executioner to await his signal before beheading him

name: James Graham
title: 1st Marquess of Montrose
quote: The covenant which I took, I own it and adhere to it. Bishops, I do not care for them. I never intended to advance their interests.
context: prior to execution by hanging, beheading and quartering

name: Eusebius Andrews
title: English royalist
context: prior to execution by beheading for treason

name: John Taylor
title: English poet
quote: How sweet it is to rest!

name: Pierre Gassendi
title: French philosopher, Catholic priest, astronomer and mathematician
quote: You see what is man's life.

name: James Ussher
title: Church of Ireland Archbishop of Armagh and Primate of All Ireland
quote: O Lord, forgive me specially my sins of omission.

name: Oliver Cromwell
title: English general and statesman, Lord Protector

name: Paul Scarron
title: French poet, dramatist and novelist
quote: Ah! mes enfans, you cannot cry as much for me as I have made you laugh in my time! I never thought that it was so easy a matter to laugh at the approach of death.

name: Cardinal Mazarin
title: Italian cardinal, diplomat and politician
quote: O, my poor soul, what is to become of thee? Whither wilt thou go?

name: Samuel Rutherford
title: Scottish pastor
quote: I bless the Lord that he gave me counsel.

name: Archibald Campbell
title: 1st Marquess of Argyll, Scottish nobleman
quote: I die not only a Protestant, but with a heart-hatred of popery, prelacy, and all superstition. Lord Jesus, receive me into Thy glory.
context: before execution by beheading

name: James Guthrie
title: Scottish Presbyterian minister
quote: I take God to record upon my soul that I would not exchange this scaffold with the palace or mitre of the greatest prelate in Britain. The covenants, the covenants shall yet be Scotland's reviving.
context: prior to execution by hanging for high treason

name: Marie Angélique Arnauld
title: Abbess of the Abbey of Port-Royal
quote: Jesus, oh Jesus, you are my God, my justice, my strength, my all.

name: Henry Vane the Younger
title: English politician, statesman and colonial governor
quote: It is a bad cause which cannot bear the words of a dying man.
context: prior to execution by beheading for treason

name: Robert Sanderson
title: English theologian and casuist
quote: My heart is fixed, O God! my heart is fixed where true joy is to be found.

name: Archibald Johnston
title: Scottish judge and statesman
quote: Abba, Father, accept this, Thy poor sinful servant, coming unto Thee through the merits of Jesus Christ. O pray, pray! praise, praise!
context: before execution by hanging

name: Anne of Austria
title: former Queen of France
quote: Monsieur de Montaigu, consider what I owe to God, the favor He has shown me, and the great indulgence for which I am beholden to Him. Observe how they are swelled; time to depart.
context: looking at her formerly beautiful hands

name: Hugh Mackail
title: Scottish martyr
quote: And now I begin my intercourse with God, which shall never be broken off. Farewell, father and mother, friends and relations; farewell, the world and all delights; farewell, sun, moon and stars! Welcome, God and Father; welcome, sweet Jesus Christ, the mediator of the new covenant; welcome, blessed Spirit of grace, the God of all consolation; welcome, glory; welcome, eternal life; and welcome, death.
context: prior to execution by hanging

name: Alonso Cano
title: Spanish painter, architect and sculptor
quote: Vex me not with this thing, but give me a simple cross, that I may adore it, both as it is in itself and as I can figure it in my mind.
context: asking a priest to take away a badly carved crucifix

name: William Davenant
title: English poet and playwright
quote: I shall have to ask leave to desist, when I am interrupted by so great an experiment as dying.
context: setting aside the manuscript of a new poem

name: Richard Mather
title: Puritan minister
quote: Far from well, yet far better than mine iniquities deserve.
context: when asked about his health

name: John Cosin
title: English churchman
context: raising his hand

name: François de La Mothe Le Vayer
title: French writer
quote: Well, my friend, what news from the Great Mogul?
context: to physician and traveler François Bernier, who had come to say goodbye to him

name: Salvator Rosa
title: Italian artist and poet
quote: Bad, bad! To judge by what I now endure, the hand of death grasps me sharply.
context: when asked how he was

name: John Milton
title: English poet and intellectual
quote: Death is the great key that opens the palace of Eternity.

name: Henri de La Tour d'Auvergne
title: Viscount of Turenne
quote: I did not mean to be killed today. ("Je ne veux point être tué aujourd'hui.")
context: struck by a cannonball at the Battle of Salzbach

name: Alexis of Russia
title: Russian Tsar
quote: I would never have married had I known that my time would be so brief. If I had known that, I would not have taken upon myself double tears.

name: Isaac Barrow
title: English Christian theologian and mathematician
quote: I have seen the glories of the world.

name: Mary Rich
title: Countess of Warwick
quote: Well, ladies, if I were one hour in heaven, I would not be again with you, as much as I love you.

name: Thomas Hobbes
title: English philosopher
quote: Now I am about to take my last voyage, a great leap in the dark.

name: John Wilmot
title: 2nd Earl of Rochester, English poet and courtier
quote: The only objection against the Bible is a bad life.

name: William Howard
title: 1st Viscount Stafford
context: to his executioner prior to beheading for alleged treason

name: William Russell
title: Lord Russell
quote: Now the bitterness of death is past.
context: after bidding farewell to his wife prior to execution by beheading for treason

name: John Owen
title: English Nonconformist church leader and theologian
quote: Stop. Change that to say, 'I am yet in the land of the dying, but I hope soon to be in the land of the living.'
context: when his secretary had written "I am still in the land of the living" in a letter in his name

name: Algernon Sidney
title: English politician
quote: I know that my Redeemer liveth. I die for the good old cause.
context: prior to execution by beheading for treason

name: Wentworth Dillon
title: 4th Earl of Roscommon, Anglo-Irish landlord, Irish peer, and poet
quote: My God, my Father, and my Friend, / Do not forsake me in the end.
context: quoting from his own translation of the "Dies irae"

name: Charles II of England
quote: I have been a most unconscionable time dying, but I beg you to excuse it.

name: James Scott
title: 1st Duke of Monmouth, illegitimate son of Charles II of England
quote: There are six guineas for you, and do not hack me as you did my Lord Russell. I have heard that you struck him three or four times. My servant will give you more gold if you do your work well.
context: to Jack Ketch, his executioner. Ketch was nervous and took several blows to behead Scott

name: James Renwick
title: Scottish minister
quote: Lord, into Thy hands I commend my spirit; for Thou hast redeemed me, Lord God of truth.
context: before execution by hanging

name: John Bunyan
title: English writer and preacher
quote: Take me, for I come to Thee.

name: John Eliot
title: Puritan missionary to the American Indians, founder of Roxbury Latin School
quote: O, come in glory! I have long waited for Thy coming. Let no dark cloud rest on the work of the Indians. Let it live when I am dead. Welcome joy!

name: Margaret Mary Alacoque
title: French Roman Catholic nun, promoter of devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus
quote: I need nothing but God, and to lose myself in the heart of Jesus.

name: George Fox
title: English Dissenter, founder of the Religious Society of Friends
quote: Never heed; the Lord's power is over all weakness and death.

name: John Flavel
title: English Presbyterian clergyman and author
quote: I know that it will be well with me.

name: Richard Baxter
title: English Puritan church leader, poet, hymnodist and theologian
quote: Death, death. O I thank Him, I thank Him. The Lord teach you to die.

name: Louise-Anastasia Serment
title: French natural philosopher and poet
quote: Nectare clausa suo, / Dignum tantorum pretium tulit illa laborum.
context: Quoting the Latin inscription on a Roman piece of amber trapping a bee; 'closed in her nectar, she receives the reward for all her labours'

name: Sarah Good
title: American woman accused of witchcraft during the Salem witch trials
quote: You are a lyer; I am no more a Witch than you are a Wizard, and if you take away my Life, God will give you Blood to drink.
context: to Reverend Nicholas Noyes prior to execution by hanging

name: Giles Corey
title: English-born American farmer
context: before being pressed to death during the Salem witch trials

name: Ulrica Eleanor the Elder
title: Queen of Sweden
quote: Yes, like that, just like that, my royal friend, raise me upward, upward!
context: to her husband holding her

name: Patrick Sarsfield
title: 1st Earl of Lucan, Irish soldier
quote: Oh, that this were for Ireland.
context: mortally wounded at the Battle of Landen

name: Suleiman I of Persia
title: Shah of Safavid Iran
context: According to the French cleric, Martin Gaudereau

name: Mary II of England
quote: My Lord, why do you not go on? I am not afraid to die.
context: when the clergyman reading the prayers for the sick paused due to being overcome by grief

name: Philip Henry
title: English Nonconformist clergyman and diarist
context: quoting 1 Corinthians 15:55

name: Hortense Mancini
title: Duchesse de Mazarin, niece of Cardinal Mazarin and mistress of Charles II of England
context: dying in financial ruin

name: John Chrysostom
title: Early Church Father and Archbishop of Constantinople
quote: Glory to God for all things! Amen.
context: while traveling deeper into exile

name: MARMADUKE STEVENSON
title: October
context: Be it known to all this day, that we suffer not as evil doers, but for conscience['] sake; this day we shall be at rest with the Lord.

name: WILLIAM ROBINSON
title: October
context: This is the day of your visitation, wherein the Lord hath visited you.This is the day the Lord is risen in his mighty power, to be avenged on all his adversaries. I suffer not as an evil doer. Mind the light that is within you; to wit the Light of Christ, of which He testified and I am now going to seal with my blood. Now ye are made manifest; I suffer for Christ in whom I live and in whom I die

name: WILLIAM LEDDRA
title: March
context: For bearing my testimony for the Lord against deceivers and the deceived, I am brought here to suffer. Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.

name: UNNAMED RINGLEADER
context: I have been among drawn Swords, flying bullets, roaring cannons, amidst all which, I knew not what Fear meant: but now I have appreciations of the dreadful wrath of God, in the other World, which I am going into, my Soul within me, is amazed at it... I pray God that I may be a warning to you all, and that I may be the last that ever shall suffer after this manner: In the fear of God I warn you to have a care of taking the Lord's name in vain. And have a care of that sin of Drunkenness, for that sin lead[s] to all manner of sins and wickedness... as I am a dying man, and to appear before that Lord within a few minutes that you may take notice of what I say to you...

name: THOMAS LUTHERLAND
title: February
context: I had rather go to an Ale-house than to any Church. Pray Young People take warning by my shameful end: keep the Sabbath truly.... I have had great Oppression upon my Spirit since I was in this prison and I thought I should never repent or confess, until Almighty God softened my hard heart and gave me grace to repent. I beg all good people to joyn in prayers with me, I have great need of your prayers.

name: SARAH GOOD
title: July
context: I am no more a witch than you are a wizard, and if you take away my life, God will give you blood to drink.

name: JULIAN
title: March
context: And now I have forsaken God, he has forsaken me, and I acknowledge he has been just in leaving me, for that I have gone from bad to worse, till for my sins I am now to die.... whereas I have been charged with and tried for burning my master's barn, I now declare as a dying man that I did not do it.... I acknowledge I deserve to die, and would confess especially my drunkenness and Sabbath-breaking, which have led me to this great Sin for which I now die

name: PATIENCE BOSTON
title: July
context: How are we condemned by the Covenant of Works, and relieved by the Covenant of Grace

name: REV. JOHN URIE
title: August
context: In the presence of God, the possessor of heaven and earth, I lift up my hands and solemnly protest I am innocent of what is laid to my charge. I appeal to the great God for my non-knowledge of Hughson, his wife, or the creature that was hanged with them [Peggy Carey, a prostitute]. I never saw them, living, dying, or dead; nor ever had I any knowledge or confederacy with white or black, as to any plot;... and I protest that the witnesses were perjured; I never knew them but at my trial.

name: WILLIAM WELCH
title: April
context: I heartily thank the good Ministers who have frequently visited me, and prayed for me. I heartily forgive my enemies. And I sincerely fly to the Blood of Jesus Christ which is able to atone for my innumerable iniquities and cleanse me from the Pollution of Sin.

name: HENRY HALBERT
title: October
context: I die in the 30th year of my age, and desire all young Men and Children to take warnings by my untimely End. I die a Protestant according to the Principles of the Lutheran Church, desiring the Prayers of all my Spectators and Hearers.

name: JOSEPH LIGHTLY
title: November
context: And as to the Woman who was my reputed Wife, she died with a Lie in her mouth, but I freely forgive those who swore to her false Declarations. I acknowledge myself to have been a notorious Sabbath-breaker, and would warn all young People against that heinous Crime. I ask forgiveness of all Men whom I have... injur'd, and pray they will forgive me, so I hope for Forgiveness of God.

name: JOSEPH ANDREWS
title: May
context: I acknowledge that I had a fair and impartial [trial] and that the Sentence I received was very just. I am now in the 39th year of my Age, and I die an unworthy member of the Church of Rome, I sincerely bewail the errors of my past life, and hope for mercy in the next. I shall conclude with exhorting you to pray for yourselves, and at the same time to petition heaven to have mercy upon my poor soul.

name: FRANCIS BURDETT PERSONAL
title: September
context: The Lord shewed me, that I had nothing in me that could commend me to God... and as I am shortly to die a shameful death, which I brought upon myself, by reason of living so long without God in the world, yet I would die this death, in the condition I am now in, rather than live in this world, to be carnally minded, as usual. I die now to live eternally. Glory be to God for his free grace bestowed on me, vile sinner. I die, though, most unworthy of the title, one of the Israel of God and an heir of glory.

name: NATHAN HALE
title: September
context: I only regret that I have but one life to lose for my country.

name: THOMAS GROSS
context: Don't you imagine that men of liberal education are more intriguing, and do more frequently deceive the world then illiterate farmers? And will you not allow that there are as many bad clergymen, in proportion to their number as any other left? As this is my opinion, why should I request their advice or prayers, in preference to other?

name: JOSEPH TAYLOR
title: May
context: This is the first time since my condemnation that I thought what it was to die. The shock was terrible... what a night of horror was the next night!... [The doctor] perceived that agony of my soul and asked me some questions of the state of my mind... and [I poured] my heart out to him... I had fortunately concealed my real name, that I might return, like the prodigal, to my parents, and live a life devoted to God and their comfort.

name: ELISHA THOMAS
title: June
context: I cannot forget to return my thanks to the Gentlemen and Ladies of the town of Dover, who so humanely petitioned his Excellency and council, for a short respite of my execution-may they enjoy long and uninterrupted happiness here, and may the best of Heaven's blessings await them hereafter. Nor must I neglect the same testimonials of kindness I have received from them during my confinement. I now recommend my soul to the allmerciful Creator of all Worlds and all Creatures, most ardently imploring the forgiveness, of may manifold transgressions, and that the redeemer would most graciously receive me to the arms of his everlasting mercy, when I leave the world.

name: RACHEL WALL
title: October
context: I likewise return my hearty thanks to the several Ministers of the town who have attended be [sic] since I have been under sentence: also to a number of other kind friends, for the care they have shewn to me both for soul and body... may God reward them all for their kindness to me. And now, into the hands of Almighty God I commit my soul, relying on his mercy, through the merits and mediation of my Redeemer, and die an unworthy member of the Presbyterian Church, in the 29th year of my age.

name: SAMUEL FROST
title: October
context: I declare that I ever had a great aversion to stealing and telling lies, and think them to be great crimes. I always meant to tell truth, and never stole, except taking a few apples from orchards may be called so.

name: EDMUND FORTIS
title: September
context: And now, as a dying man, I recommend to the charity of Christian neighbors, my distressed wife Lydia, who I leave with two small children, destitute of everything to help themselves with, and she big with child. And I desire the prayers of all good people to God for them and myself.

name: ABRAHAM JOHNSTONE
title: July
context: I most solemnly declare with my dying breath... that I am innocent, and unknowing to the death ofThomas Read the Guinea, Negro [that I die for].... And now having settled my worldly affairs I shall close and prepare to depart in peace. I've kissed this paperand bid it convey the kiss to you my love: and now my dear Sally, I bid you-oh heavens! I bid you my dear wife! Not the Farewell of a day, month, nor year-but an eternal farewell-I earnestly beg your prayers for me and may God protect, preserve, prosper, and bless you, is the dying prayer of your dotingly fond husband...

name: STEPHEN SMITH
title: October
context: When I think how I have sinned against the great God, my heart breaks and tears run from my eyes... I forgive every body, and hope that God will have mercy on me. Now in the 28th year of my age, I commit my spirit in to the hands of a merciful... God and hope he will receive me for his great mercy's sake. I die in peace with all mankind, and beg that all people will take warning by my awful end.

name: JEREBOAM O. BEAUCHAMP
title: July
context: Your husband is dying happy! For you I lived, for you I die! I hear you groan! I hope you may yet be recovered! If you are, live till it is God's will to take you, and prepare to meet me in a better world!

name: NAT TURNER
title: November
context: It's in God's hands now.

name: JOHN STONE
title: July
context: I swear to you, sheriff, I'm an innocent man. I have never been to the Thompson house, and I never saw Mrs. Thompson on the day that she was murdered. I believe that there were two of them-two men-who did the murder that I've been wrongly accused of. Even if I did know their names, I'd swing before I would have their blood upon me.

name: AARON STOOKEY
title: September
context: Lord Jesus, have mercy on my soul. God bless you. I hope I shall be better off. My dear fellow citizens‚ÄîI now stand here before you to die, and I hope and believe my soul will be saved, I trust my God has forgiven me. You must all beware of Rum; for rum has been the cause of placing me here to meet this awful fate. I warn you all not to touch the intoxicating bowl, for it will eventually get the advantage of you all. I am sorry to die under the gallows but the laws must be carried out, and die I must, remember what I say, Rum has done it all, and I hope all who are here will be taking warning by it. God bless you all, may God have mercy on my soul, and receive me into his kingdom. Good-by, God bless you and my friends.

name: JAMES WILSON
title: November
context: Here we go, pals, 'round and 'round.

name: CREED TURNER
title: December
context: I committed the deed and now I'm paying for it. If I had to do it over again I would. I leave my written words for you all to read.

name: OTTO GRUNZIG
title: February
context: Mr. Sheriff, you are a good man, and I have nothing to say, except that I protest my innocence. In my last dying words, I say I am innocent! I am innocent! I am innocent! Justice in this country is bad. I was not guilty, and the Jury did wrong in convicting me.

name: WILLIAM B. SHEPPARD
title: July
context: I feel like an innocent man.

name: WILLIAM H. LIPSEY
title: November
context: Make the time as short as you can, for I am fainting.

name: STEPHEN SHORT
title: January
context: I want all of you to take warning by me. See what whisky and bad women have brought me to. I have been to a good many hanging scrapes myself, and thought it was great fun, but I never thought I'd be hung myself.This is the work of Capt. Whisky. I am willing to die for the life of the man that I took. Talk of pleasure-I have tried all kinds of it, about shanties drunk, and everywhere else, but I have had more real pleasure up in that old jail, than ever before in all my life; and chains on my legsbig, heavy chains at that. I just took off this old coat, and whipped Satan clean out, fair. I've made my election sure, I think. Yes, sir, I think my election is sure.

name: JEREMIAH V. CRAINE
title: October
context: Susan, receive me; I will soon be with you.

name: DANFORTH HARTSON
title: July
context: For God's sake, don't do that again.

name: ALBERT STAUB
title: April
context: I wish to speak a few words to my German countrymen. You all see what the temptings ofthe devil have brought me to, and I wish you to be warned by my fate. Keep away from bad company, and let liquor alone. Do not covet the money of others, and do not let your wish for money lead you into crime. I implore you to get religion, to go to church, and to pray to God, for there is more rejoicing in Heaven over one sinner who repents than ninety-nine that need no repentance. Be warned by me, and do not commit sin. Amen.

name: JOHN BROWN
title: December
context: No, I am ready at any time; but do not keep me needlessly waiting.

name: ANN BILANSKI
title: March
context: Don't let a crowd see me. I am willing to meet my God, but I don't want to have a crowd see me die. I die without having any mercy shown on me, or justice. I die for the good of my soul and not for murder. Your courts of justice are not courts ofjustice-but I will yet get justice, in heaven.

name: JOHN CRUMMINS
title: March
context: I feel deeply grateful to the people of New York and to all present who have had anything to do with me, for the sympathy they have expressed and the kindness they have extended toward me, and I ask God to bless and reward you all for your great attention. I feel sorry for the crime I have committed, but it was done under the influence of passion and without a design to do murder. I hope my wife and children will be taken care of by my friends, and that my disgrace will not fall upon them.I hope, too, that McHenry's wife and children will be looked to by my friends. I trust to receive the mercy of the Almighty.

name: HDAINYANKA
title: December
context: You have deceived me. You told me that if we followed the advice of General Sibley, and gave ourselves up to the whites, all would be well; no innocent man would be injured. I have not killed, wounded or injured a white man, or any white persons. I have not participated in the plunder of their property; and yet to-day I am set apart for execution, and must die in a few days, while men who are guilty will remain in prison. My wife is your daughter, my children are your grandchildren. I leave them all in your care and under your protection. Do not let them suffer; and when my children are grown up, let them know that their father died because he followed the advice of his chief, and without having the blood of a white man to answer for to the Great Spirit.

name: HIRAM REYNOLDS
title: August
context: I see it now, it is all bright.

name: THOMAS R. DAWSON
title: April
context: You may break my neck, but you won't break the seal of manhood.

name: JOHN YATES BEALL
title: February
context: I protest against the execution of this sentence. It is absolute murder-brutal murder! I die in the defense and service of my country. I beg you to make haste!

name: MARCELLUS JEROME CLARKE
title: March
context: I am a regular Confederate soldier, and have served in the Confederate army four years. I fought under General Buckner at Fort Donelson, and belonged to General Morgan's command when he entered Kentucky. I have assisted, and have taken many prisoners, and have always treated them kindly. I was wounded at Cynthiana and cut from my command. I have been in Kentucky ever since. I could prove that I am a regular Confederate soldier, and I hope to die for the Confederate cause.

name: MARY SURRATT
title: July
context: Please don't let me fall.

name: HENRY WILSON
title: December
context: I had made a request not to have my photograph taken, for fear my friends would recognize me. Somebody else made aa request that it should be taken, and Chase [the sheriff] paid more attention to them than to me, and let them try to take it as I came out. You can see what kind of man this Chase is, and if I had a chance I would take his photograph d-d quick. I don't think they got a good one. So my friends will not know it. Perhaps my photograph will be the means of finding out who I am, but I doubt it d-dly. I have nothing more to say, and you may go on as soon as you please, for it is no consolation to me to be kept standing here in the cold.

name: BARNEY OLWELL
title: January
context: I don't know as I've got anything to say; I am going to be hanged, and don't want to make a stump speech.

name: ROBERT S. DODGE
title: November
context: The time will come when my innocence will be proven, and then Bob Dodge will haunt you for his murder.

name: TOM DULA
title: May
context: Gentlemen, do you see this hand? Does it tremble? I never hurt a hair of that girl's head.

name: GEORGE TRUMAN
title: May
context: The sands of a brief existence have nearly run; my eyes are closing forever upon the beauties ofthis lesser world, to open, I hope and trust and pray, upon the splendor of a better. I bid all a last farewell.

name: JOHN BOYER
title: April
context: Look at me! I no cry; I no woman; I man. I die brave!

name: ISSAC M. WEAVER
title: January
context: I have always wished not to die with my boots on; please pull them off.

name: MARSHALL MARTIN
title: January
context: Gentlemen, I am here to die, but I am an innocent man compared to that woman. She deserves death ten times more than I do.

name: WILLIAM WRIGHT WHEATLEY
title: August
context: My Friends: You are now gazing upon a very unfortunate man, who is called forth to bid a final adieu to this cheating and sinful world. God of infinite mercy have compassion upon a poor sinner and save me from perdition. My friends, I desire to thank all the good people of Montana, and now ask God to bless you all and those dear ones so far away. I am now about to offer up my life. I make this statement to show you how unfortunate I am and as a warning to you all, just as I go to that awful future, to meet my God. May God bless you all. I am ready, God have mercy on my soul.

name: ALCEE HARRIS
title: November
context: I'm going to Jesus.

name: MARSHALL CRAIN
title: January
context: I must make a statement in regard to this matter. I feel it my duty to God and to man to do so. I am guilty of killing the two men. My soul is stained with blood and my punishment is just. I hope all will forgive me. I pray God to guide and prosper this country. I am the murderer of William Spence. And George W. Sisney. That is all I have to say.

name: ISAIAH EVANS
title: May
context: I had a square trial. Everything the witnesses said was pretty much true. I felt at the time that I ought to have done it, and afterward I felt I did wrong. I tell you it's a hard thing when a man brings it on himself, but whisky did it.

name: GEORGE SHERRY
title: June
context: I bid you farewell, my sister, likewise to this world of sin. But 'tis hard, 'tis hard, my sister, to part from friends and kin. To be led like a brute to the slaughter, to die by the hangman's hand. To perish like a guilty felon, condemned by the laws of the land.

name: MARTIN BERGIN
title: January
context: I have nothing at all to say. I will die like a Game Man. That is all I have to say.

name: WILLIAM MERRICK
title: January
context: I have a great deal I would like to say, but it would not be worth while to say anything. The State of Indiana to-day, in the sight of that Court-house, is doing an unjust thing to one of her citizens. I say, as I have said before to this people and to the world, I am innocent of the charge. When that drop fails and my life goes out, it will be eternal peace. I wish to say no more.

name: HENRY F. ANDREWS
title: May
context: Mercy! Mercy! Mercy! Don't hang me! I can't die! I'm not ready to die! I don't want to die!

name: ANDREW TRACY
title: December
context: I forgive my enemies.

name: JOHN VANDERPIED
title: February
context: All young men take warning and never be guilty of theft, however small, because they might deserve the small penalty I am about to suffer. I have five minutes to live. I can think of Heaven in that time.While there is life there is hope.

name: MATILDA CARTER
title: January
context: Folks, hear me, as I'se to be hanged. I'se free from any guilt about Nash Carter. I had a child by another man, but was smart enough to keep my husband from knowing it.

name: EMELINE MEAKER
title: March
context: I have got nothing more to say. May God forgive you for murdering me. You are about to hang an innocent woman-innocent as the man that stands there.

name: HENRY DICKERSON
title: September
context: You young saints and sinners, take warning and let whisky alone. It was whisky that brought me here. I did not kill the man, it was whisky; but I am come here now, and God has pardoned me. My way is clear before me. I have nearly come up, and am now pulling myself into the light of glory.... I advise all you saints and sinners not to fool too much with whisky. Here I am, a hardworking man, brought here by whisky. Steele told me in the spirit that if could he come and speak for me he would say a good word for me. I trust to meet you all with my Jesus.... God bless you all.

name: MARGARET HARRIS
title: October
context: I am going to tell the truth before God. I am innocent of the charge. I did not poison Leia Lewis, and I hope to meet her in heaven. My kin people brought me to this, and I want them to pray to meet me in heaven. I have heard they said hanging was too good for me, that I ought to be burned. Farewell all, I am going to die. I hope this poor man will be released, as he is innocent before God.

name: ROBERT MARTIN
title: January
context: I am almost sorry you woke me up. I was having pleasant dreams. No! I can't tell you what they were, because I can't recall them. I only know that I was in a most delightful frame of mind.

name: EDWARD RECTOR
title: January
context: Where is my little boy? Look at me, my son, and take warning.

name: JOHN OWENS
title: March
context: What time is it? I wish you'd hurry up. I want to get to hell in time for dinner.

name: ALLEN J. ADAMS
title: April
context: None of your business. What in the _ do you want to take a man's life in this way for, you __ cutthroats. Hurry up, old man, or Clark will want another drink of whisky. If you don't look out, I may fall through and sue the city for damages.

name: JOHN THOMAS ROSS
title: September
context: Gentlemen, one and all, I am about to die for a crime of which I am guilty and I am perfectly willing to go. I have nothing to regret, but I am sorry that I, John Thomas Ross, have to pay it all. As Marshall Frey knows, there are others who are as much guilty as I am. I am glad I have been brought to this and I am thankful to God for bringing me here. I have no hard feelings against anyone. Had not God stopped me in my bad career I might never have gotten here. I am going where there is no trouble or sighing and where I will have rest forever. Let me go. Lord Jesus, remember me.

name: ADOLPH FISCHER
title: November
context: This is the happiest day of my life.

name: AUGUST SPIES
title: November
context: The time will come when our silence will be more powerful than the voices you strangle today.

name: GEORGE ENGEL
title: November
context: Hurrah for anarchy!

name: ALBERT PARSONS
title: November
context: May I be allowed to speak? Oh, men of America! May I be allowed the privilege of speech even at the last moment? Harken to the voice of the people

name: JOSE RAMIREZ
title: December
context: Good-by for all my gentlemens [sic], good-by. I am going to die like a man; isn't that so gentlemen?

name: JOHN PATRICK HART
title: February
context: I wish you all a restful conscience and a useful life on this life on this earth. I hope when you come through this door you will bring some little child that has no father and mother on this earth for protection. That is all I have to say on this earth, Good-bye.

name: PIERRE PAUL
title: December
context: I killed the men. I do not regret [it], but they tell me it was wrong. If so, I am sorry. You see how I am here. Try and help my people. If so, tell them how I died, and warn them not to do as I did, or they may die, as I have to die. Be kind to my people and see that they do not want. I am glad you come and I thank you for being here and for what you have done for me. See that I am buried with my people.

name: JAMES M. EUBANKSs
title: January
context: Oh, Jesus, I give myself to Thee; Thy will be done. I hope that this will be a warning to others.

name: CHARLES WALL
title: March
context: I have this to say: That I know nothing about the murder. The people bore false witness against me. I hired Mr. Platt to defend me and told him all I knew, but he turned against me and went over to the other side. That is the reason I am on the scaffold to-day. If I did the deed and knew what I was doing, I ought to be hanged for it, but I did not know what I was doing.

name: WALTER HOLMES
title: February
context: I only wish to say that the statement I have made about the crime with which I stand charged is true. I must say that since I have been here, no Protestant minister has come near me. When the priests came, they were kind to me, and I can only say that I die happy and a Catholic. That is all.
